reviewText:
Early Access Review

Immune is a very early access survival game. There's you, there's zombies, there's friendly and unfriendly NPCs and, sometimes, there's other players. I say sometimes because the game is still very new and very raw and thus there's not a lot of people on, or stuff to keep people hooked.

The game itself has a simple premise so far: you're trying to survive post zombie apocalypse. You look around for food and resources, you kill/escape zombies, you hopefully team up with people to survive. There's a few things you can craft, you can plant a couple things, you can go through boxes and stuff, and you can punch trees (and other stuff) for resources.
There's not much of a story, not that I've seen yet anyway, but it's a nice game so far. Simple, obviously has a long way to go still, but promising all the same. It was a bit hard for me at first to get on my feet, but once I got a friend to play with it was a lot easier and faster to get resources and share them.

The game played well in my computer, which I deem a toaster.

Of course, because it's early access, there's not much content yet, things still need modifying, and what you see now might not be what you get in the long run.

Downsides:
- Not a lot of variety on stuff (only a few types of food, only a few types of stuff to craft, amount of items needed to craft stuff seems a bit odd at times)
- Cars super hard to handle with the drifting
- Servers can get a bit kick happy sometimes, also they are new so they're mostly empty (which can be both good and bad)
- Seems a bit difficult to hunt stuff when you're soloing (zombies are too strong for someone with just a stick, evil npcs kill you asap too)
- Characters lack variety (no choosing gender, they all look the same, but at least they're cute)
- You can not move stuff once you place them down, some stuff have very short durability (like crops, walls)

These are all stuff that could be easily fixed (and probably will be, or will at least change) as the game progresses, though, so I wouldn't just discard the game for it.

Upsides:
- Cuteish graphics
- Actually nice to co-op with friends
- You can use the cars found around!
- You can loot your own backpack if you get back to where you died (thus recovering your stuff) :)
- You can make current buildings into your own safehouse
- The developer replies quickly to issues, and he's very nice and friendly


Immune still needs a lot of work, but for early access it's not a bad game (I mean, responsive developer and mostly functional game. I've seen worse in early access!).

I still don't know that it'd be worth full price in its current state, but this could become quite a fun little-big survival game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.
I will start by saying Immune is an early Access game, so take that into consideration when reading my review.

Immune identifies itself as a Massively Multiplayer Survival game. The game has been released almost two months at the time of writing, and when I booted it up, I found I was the only person online. Like all the other survival games out there today, you are thrown into the game to literally just survive, there are no missions, quests or tasks to complete, it‚Äôs just an open sandbox, you create your own story/challenges.

Immune is one of the first games of this genre that I have played, and I have to give them credit, their tutorial is actually quite good, it's very basic, but it does well in explaining the key mechanics such as chopping down trees and making simple items such as camp fires. Sadly though, the tutorial is probably the only small gleaming positive coming out of Immune at the moment. Once you finish the tutorial, you are thrown onto an island, with no sort of guidance as to what to do, you are just out to fend for yourself. I wandered around for a while and found absolutely nothing to do. Nothing at all. Okay I chopped a few trees down, then what? Build a fire. Ok....in order to build anything remotely interesting you need to chop trees down constantly for half an hour...

The graphics are poor compared to other games of this type, it can be played at higher resolutions, but really, there is no point, it still looks the same in lower resolutions. There is no music, the sound effects are also none existent also, at one point I had to tab out of game because I thought I was muted, nope, just no sound.

The controls are also horrible too, space bar is your attack button? To me that just shouts out as an issue. I mean, it would be a little redeemable if they incorporated mouse controls, I mean we are playing on PC right? All of the controls just feel wrong sadly. Don't even get me started on attempting to drive the one truck I managed to bump into, the control on this thing was terrible, and the physics...well, there are none, I was driving, then suddenly I started sliding, it was just awful. I finally quitted the game when I was driving, hoping to be able to get through what looked like a small pool of water, only for my car to explode on impact of even touching the water slightly.

The idea behind a MMO Survival Game is really good, the likes of Rust have done really well out of it, but right now Immune is in no state to be played, and especially for the price of ¬£12,99. Maybe wait a couple of months while this is still being worked on and maybe some more content and fixes will be in place.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Playing Immune was a fun and challenging time trying to survive in a world of zombies, hunger and gas masked pyschos trying to kill me. I liked the crafting, scavenging, collaborative play you can have as you and friends search the landscape for food and supplies. It definitely felt good getting enough crafting material to build my first weapon and some armor. Plus not sure I have played any other game where i had to chase down a chicken so i could harvest the meat and the feeling of victory of killing it.

On the bad side this game does have some quirks to it. Granted it is still early access so problems are going to arise and be present that will hopefully be fixed. between enemies not dropping loot sometimes, to killing a guy who is shooting a gun at you, but getting nothing. Makes me feel a break in the survive mentality. If i kill someone who is using a gun that gun should be on them or at least ammo.

Crafting is another aspect i am looking forward to seeing what is coming. There are a number of good items you can make, but when you hit the highest level as of now, it kind of makes you wonder if carrying all your crafting supplies is needed once you make the items that can help you.

Overall Immune is fun and has a lot of potential. I am definitely looking forward to the updates coming and see where the game goes from here. I have a more in depth review linked here. http://www.omnicomic.com/2015/05/review-immune.html if you want to see more of my thoughts on the game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen I first started playing this by myself, I started to panic a bit. Was this to be yet another bare bones, early access survival game destined to end up unplayed with the others? Then some real players showed up in a jeep, handed me some supplies, and away we went to loot and murder NPCs for their stuff. The community is tiny but awesome, helpful, and fun to play with. After feeling screwed over by Reign of Kings and other cynical, survivor based games, I'm happy to play this little diamond in the rough with loads of potential. The art style is great, and the top-down feel evokes Zombies Ate My Neighbors and other games from my childhood. The price may be a little high, but I'm confident you won't care once you start to play with others. There are certainly some bugs and kinks to work out (driving is hillariously bad but fun), but the game remains stable. No regrets making my purchase.

Introduction
What would you do in a post apocalyptic setting? Be a lone hero, form a group to survive with or maybe hide and wait for the sweet release of death? Immune is here to help answer that question for you. With little more than the shirt on your back, you will be thrust into life or death situations along with other players trying to survive.

Story
There isn‚Äôt much of a story to speak of in Immune. You spawn as a generic character and after a few hints on newbie island you‚Äôre left to fend for yourself in a barren wasteland. All player generated characters look the same, no option to customize or change the gender, and there are no backstories at all. I don‚Äôt even know where in the world I am nor what happened." The non-playable characters also offer no help as all they do is offer to sell you  things
